Kent, 
   Thank you. I also posted the same question on Dev-list. Sorry for 
my double posting. You can ignore the other one. 

   Junit is coooooool. It's deeply in our development process. 


Chester

--- In junit@y..., "kentlbeck" <kentbeck@c...> wrote:
> --- In junit@y..., "Chesterxgchen" <chesterxgchen@y...> wrote:
> > Hi, 
> >   I am trying to understand the design patterns used in the JUnit 
> > code. I noticed following piece of codes, which I am not quite 
sure 
> > why it is written in such way. I hope some one can help me to 
> explain 
> > it. 
> > 
> >   So the TestRunner.java Run() ... cals TestSuite.java 's Run() 
> which 
> > in turns calls TestResult's method. 
> > 
> > 
> >    Notice that Run() does not directly call
> >     test.RunBare() but instead, using anynomous class
> > and defined a protect() method in the class. And using  
runProtected
> > () method to invoked this method .
> > 
> > 		Protectable p= new Protectable() {
> > 			public void protect() throws Throwable {
> > 				test.runBare();
> > 			}
> > 		};
> > 		runProtected(test, p);
> > 
> >   My question is why this written in such way ? Why not call 
> > test.RunBare() directly ? 
> 
> This was necessary to factor out commonality between TestCase and 
> TestSetup.
> 
> Kent
